snippet: Placing students in clusters according to ability, a tactic once rejected over concerns that it fostered inequality, has re-emerged in classrooms all over the country.
abstract: Grouping children in clusters according to their ability, tactic that lost favor in the 1980s and 1990s, has re-emerged in classrooms all over the country; trend has surprised education experts who believed criticisms about inequality of such grouping had all but ended its use.
lead_paragraph: Placing students in clusters according to ability, a tactic once rejected over concerns that it fostered inequality, has re-emerged in classrooms all over the country.

headline.seo: Grouping Students by Ability Regains Favor With Educators
